utterances: That's right.
In fact, the only cookie of the canonical cookies that is the same by both bakers is Thin Mints.
All right.
So let's get to the heart of this issue, which is I need something else to do with these cookies 'cause I don't want to eat them on their own anymore.
I think let's start with something simple and work our way up.
If you're getting tired of Girl Scout Cookies, the first thing I would say is consider altering their serving temperature.
For Thin Mints, store them in the fridge.
Yes.
You put a little chill on the mint.
It brings that spark of a fresh mint flavor to the fore.
It will reinvigorate your Thin Mints.
Samoas, or Caramel deLites, I would recommend warming them a little bit.
Get that caramel and that chocolate a little oozy.
OK.
If you want to get a little more complicated, you could start adding a savory element.
Could you?
You could.
I've done experimentation combining potato chips with Samoas...
Come on.
Or Caramel deLites.
Yes.
You put a thin spread of cream cheese on the top, and then you can fuse a potato chip to it.
You're adding crunch and you're adding salt.
With the cream cheese, that's brave.
Well, there's evidence in England actually, where a boy was tried and subsequently hanged as a pirate, and he was 10 years old.

When this particular group of pirates robbed this ship that was leaving Antigua - I mean, leaving Jamaica - they also, the captain of the ship also testified that a black slave and an Indian were set free by the pirates and subsequently given freedom on board this pirate ship.
It was really an outlaw experiment in democracy.
And a third of the people that we know now were of African origin, most of whom were former slaves, who were pirates during the 18th century.
And so even after the experience of watching the pirates ransack his ship with his mother aboard, you know, the kid wanted to join the pirates.
Well, one's left to wonder, you know?
I mean, Savage's account is very brief.
But it's an account that he made to the authorities.
And one wonders what really - was this really his mother?
Was it, you know, a cruel stepmother who was taking him somewhere where he didn't want to go?
But the fact remains that he did, he did abandon the ship.
The pirates did accept him.
And three months later he was, you know, was killed in a shipwreck here off of Cape Cod.
And we found this material, you know, several years ago.
But it was only recently that the whole story came together, as they so often do here, as we continue to investigate this incredible shipwreck.
See, these people robbed over 50 different ships.
So we have a cross-section of cultural material here that's really unprecedented in underwater archaeology.
I understand that some of the objects, including poor John King's remains, are going to be going on tour soon.
They will be.

And we're working with National Geographic right now designing an exhibit that we hope to have on the road some time early next year and, you know, of all of the various artifacts that we've uncovered from the shipwreck.
So if you ever get the urge to run away to sea with a pirate, think twice.
Three months later you could be crushed beneath a cannon off the coast of Cape Cod.
Well, it's - last year, at the very end of last year, we found 15 more cannon.
And we've been looking for the stern section of the ship now for over 20 years.
And last - at the very end of last year we think we may have discovered it.
So it should be a very interesting summer for us here on Cape Cod.
Well, have a good time.
Thank you so much.
Barry Clifford, an explorer with the Whydah Sea-lab and Learning Center in Provincetown, Massachusetts.
And he joined us today from his office there.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan.
Soundbite of music
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News, I'm Scott Simon.
Defense Secretary Robert Gates is scheduled to brief President Bush today about what he learned on his visit to Iraq.
Mr. Gates was in Baghdad to consult with U.S.
and Iraqi military commanders on strategies for pulling the country out of its spiral into civil war.
He also spoke with Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki.
He came away saying that the United States and Iraq are substantially in agreement on a way forward.
NPR's Corey Flintoff joins us from Baghdad.
Corey, thanks very much for being with us.
Good morning, Scott.
And any signs you can recognize about what Secretary Gates might tell President Bush today?

Well, Gates really didn't tip his hand about what his thinking might be, but given that he seems to have talked with the same players as former secretary Rumsfeld and other administration officials, it's really hard to imagine the president is going to hear anything very radically new today.
Now, his visit, Secretary Gates's visit to Iraq lasted three days.
That's comparatively long for a U.S.
official.
Did he seem to cover more ground than what we've seen in other visits?
The security situation really does make it difficult for top American officials to get around here, because they're just especially high value targets.
So he may have heard some new ideas, but we don't know whether he's heard from any new advisors.

You know, in this day and age of secure and instantaneous communication, you don't have to fly 10 hours in a tube - no matter how nice the secretary of defense's plane I assume would be - to talk to your top generals, and for that matter Iraqi leaders.
Why an extended high-profile visit like this?
Well, I think it's important for Mr. Gates to develop these personal relationships with his commanders.
That's something he can't very well do in a video teleconference.
And then there's the symbolic value of having the new defense boss be seen on the ground here in the war zone.
And you know, you actually do get some sense of the war in the places he visited.
I mean you can hear explosions and gunfire practically any day from the Green Zone.
What is in effect the effect of a visit like this on the American public and Mr. Gates's own profile, and for that matter, the Iraqi public?
Gates also stressed that the Iraqi leaders told him that they want American support, but they want to take the lead in security operations, especially in regaining control of Baghdad.
So that's very much in keeping with what the administration's been saying about moving U.S.
troops into an advisory role.

But I guess to top this off, Mr. Gates apparently indicated today that he thought Iraqi and American leaders were substantially in agreement, even though we don't necessarily know what that agreement is.
Yes.
And he suggested - this came after a visit, a talk with Maliki, and he seemed confident.
He said that there were details that remained to be worked out and that lower level officials were going to be working them out.
But he seemed to be confident that they were on the same page.
NPR's Corey Flintoff in Baghdad, thank you.
Warren Stern is Senior Coordinator for Nuclear Safety with the State Department, working on the international project to recover the Chernobyl reactor.
At our web site, NPR.org, you can find photos of Chernobyl today.
You can also read longer excerpts of the stories from Chernobyl's survivors.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Cohen.
Scrapping the car czar.
President Obama has chosen not to appoint one person to oversee the restructuring of the troubled auto industry.
For more on why the president is switching gears we're joined now by Justin Hyde of the Detroit Free Press.
And Justin, why did President Obama decide to get rid of this car czar position?
Well, it's becoming clear that the auto industry is probably going to have too many problems for just one person to handle.

GM and Chrysler are going to be submitting plans to the administration tomorrow to explain how they deserve the 17.4 billion that the government has lent them and whether they might be able to receive even more aid in the future.
The Obama administration has several very tough questions to answer about the future of this industry and hundreds of thousands of jobs that are tied into it.
It's just going to take more work than one person can give.
So in lieu of a car czar, there will be this Presidential Task Force on Autos.
Who will be heading up that group?
It will be headed by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geitner and National Economic Council Director Lawrence Summers, the two top economic people in the Obama administration.
It'll also pool staffers from several different departments throughout the government, including Transportation, Labor, and the EPA.
You mentioned Tim Geithner, Larry Summers.
Both gentlemen already have quite a bit on their plates.
Isn't there some concern about taking on the auto industry in addition to everything else?
There may be some concern, but I don't know if they have any choice.
Just Friday, the supplier industry came to Treasury and put forth a proposal where it would receive up to $25 billion in aid.
It did so because it was warning that given the production cuts the automakers have been forced to make this year, there may be a wave of bankruptcies in the supplier industry.
They may need aid before the end of February.
